div.head: Common Music Notation Ornaments
div.p: This module makes available symbols for indicating ornaments typical of Common Music Notation (CMN). These symbols have different resultions depending on a large number of factors such as time period, location, composer, scribe, etc. The ornamentation symbols here described, therefore, are not bound to a specific realization; they are, instead, meant to encode the typology of the symbol and its position on the staff. This guidelines, nonetheless, will also describe commonly accepted realizations for each type of symbol.

Ornaments are formulae of embellishment that can be realized by adding supplemnetary notes to one or more notes of the melody. Many ornament symbols are usually written above or belove a note, but other have a more complex written expression such as those that involve multiple notes and/or include grace notes to specify conluding turns or variations.

Alternatively or additionally, the relationship with a note can be expressed in terms of beats with the attribute tstamp. For example, assuming that the following measure is in 2/2, the mordent would be related to the note on the first beat.
The following sections will introduce each element in detail for all types of ornaments supported.

div.head: Mordents
div.p: There are two common types of mordents: normal or lower mordent and inverted or uppermordent.

The type is specified with the attribute form, which accepts the following values:
norm
normal mordent, e.g., performed as the written note, followed by its lower neighbor, with a return to the written note
inv
inverted mordent, e.g., performed as the principal note, followed by its upper neighbor, with a return to the principal note
